title: Run OO flows from Service Management
content:
The following procedure assumes that you have already an OO flow available and have set up an integration with OO. 

You can run an Execute Operations Orchestration (OO) flow rule to run an OO flow at two levels:

  • Entity/Workflow level: At this level, the Execute Operations Orchestration (OO) flow rule template contains an additional parameter ("expression") that allows you to specify a condition for triggering the execution of the OO flow.
    Caution: Use caution when running OO flows with this rule, because doing so on a large number of records may downgrade the system performance. Additionally, a massive or improper OO business rule configuration will impact other integrations that are configured on the same OPB agent and may cause a delay of several minutes or even hours in integration tasks depending on the number of tasks and the server load.
  • Record level

To run OO flows from Service Management

  1. Set up a business rule to run OO flows. You can do so at the entity/entity workflow level or at the record level.

    To run an OO flow at the entity level or entity workflow level:

    1. From the main menu, click Administration > Configuration > Studio.
    2. Open an entity. This can be an out-of-the-box entity or a custom entity. For example, open Request.
    3. Select the entity name or select a workflow phase under the entity name. Take Request for example. Select Request and then select Processes and Rules, or select Support > Fulfillment > First line support and then click the Rules tab on the right-side pane.
    4. In the After applying changes section, click Add.
    5. Select If...Then...rule, and then select the Execute Operations Orchestration flow template and then OK.

    To run an OO flow at the record level:

    1. Select the required record in the relevant manager (for example, open a Request record). Select the Task plan/Plan and Execute tab.

    2. Hover over the Start button and click the Edit button. Select Automated task from the pop-up menu.

    3. In the New automatic task dialog box, under Business rule, click Set rule.

    4. In the Set rule dialog box, select Execute Operations Orchestration (OO) flow and click OK.

  2. Click the expression parameter in the business rule to specify a condition for triggering the execution of the OO flow.
    Note: This parameter is available only when you open the business rule template from the entity/workflow level.

  3. Click the OO endpoint parameter in the business rule to select the endpoint. Select the endpoint you defined at the beginning of the procedure and click OK.

  4. Click the flow name parameter in the business rule to select the Operations Orchestration flow to run. Enter a string in the Search window to search for a flow. Select the required flow and click OK.

  5. Click the flow parameters parameter in the business rule to configure the input parameters of the Operations Orchestration flow. For each parameter, enter a value in Simple mode or enter an Expression language phrase.

    Click the Expression Language button to toggle between these options. When the button is selected (blue), the field is in Expression Language mode. When it's not selected (white), the field is in Simple mode. For a full list of Expression Language functions, see Expression Language functions and syntax.

    Parameters marked with an asterisk are required fields. For information on the Operations Orchestration input parameters, refer to Use OO Studio in the OO documentation for the version of OO you have integrated with.

    Example: Use OO Studio

    Note For encrypted parameters, you can't enter an Expression Language phrase.

    When you are done, click OK.

  6. Click the Record fields parameter to map the Operations Orchestration flow output to record fields. For each Operations Orchestration output field, you must select either a record field or predefined user option, as follows:

    • To map an Operations Orchestration output field to a record field, click Add field to add a row. In the left column, select a field from the drop-down list. In the right column, enter the name of the relevant Operations Orchestration output field.

    • To map an Operations Orchestration output field to a record user option, click Add user option to add a row. In the left column, enter the name of a predefined user option for this record. In the right column, enter the name of the relevant Operations Orchestration output field.

    Note: Operations Orchestration output field mapping is only supported when the Operations Orchestration flow is running successfully.

    When you are done, click OK.

  7. If you set a business rule from the task planner, after the task runs, you can click the task to open a summary dialog displaying details of the task. The Business rules tab displays the business rule with the selected parameters, the Task start time and end time, and the Task ID. You can click the Task ID to go directly to the flow execution page for the selected flow in Operations Orchestration.

Run OO flows in OO RAS

If you need to execute flows in remote data centers and networks you must install Operations Orchestration Remote Action Service (OO RAS). For more information on how to install OO RAS, see Install OO RAS

Example use cases:

  • If you have installed OO Central on Linux and want to run flows using Microsoft .NET Framework content, such as the OO content for Microsoft System Center Virtual Machine Manager, you must install OO RAS on a Microsoft Windows target, create a worker group, and assign a worker to it.
  • If you have installed OO Central on Windows, you must create a worker group and assign a worker to it.
